    # 2.æ•°æ®åº“çš„ä¸‰å¤§èŒƒå¼

    • ç¬¬ä¸€èŒƒå¼ï¼šç¡®ä¿æ¯åˆ—ä¿æŒåŸå­æ€§ï¼Œæ•°æ®open in new windowè¡¨ä¸­çš„æ‰€æœ‰å­—æ®µå€¼éƒ½æ˜¯ä¸å¯åˆ†è§£çš„åŸå­å€¼ã€‚

    • ç¬¬ä¸‰èŒƒå¼ï¼šç¡®ä¿æ¯åˆ—éƒ½å’Œä¸»é”®åˆ—ç›´æ¥ç›¸å…³è€Œä¸æ˜¯é—´æ¥ç›¸å…³

    # 3.MySQLçš„æ•°æ®open in new windowç±»å‹æœ‰å“ªäº›

    # 3.1 æ•°å­—

    • BIT[(*M*)\]open in new window

      A bit-value type. M indicates the number of bits per value, from 1 to 64. The default is 1 if M is omitted.

    • TINYINT[(*M*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      A very small integer. The signed range is -128 to 127. The unsigned range is 0 to 255.

    • BOOLopen in new window, BOOLEANopen in new window

      These types are synonyms for TINYINT(1)open in new window. A value of zero is considered false. Nonzero values are considered true:

      mysql> SELECT IF(0, 'true', 'false');
+------------------------+
| IF(0, 'true', 'false') |
+------------------------+
| false                  |
+------------------------+

mysql> SELECT IF(1, 'true', 'false');
+------------------------+
| IF(1, 'true', 'false') |
+------------------------+
| true                   |
+------------------------+

mysql> SELECT IF(2, 'true', 'false');
+------------------------+
| IF(2, 'true', 'false') |
+------------------------+
| true                   |
+------------------------+

      However, the values TRUE and FALSE are merely aliases for 1 and 0, respectively, as shown here:

      mysql> SELECT IF(0 = FALSE, 'true', 'false');
+--------------------------------+
| IF(0 = FALSE, 'true', 'false') |
+--------------------------------+
| true                           |
+--------------------------------+

mysql> SELECT IF(1 = TRUE, 'true', 'false');
+-------------------------------+
| IF(1 = TRUE, 'true', 'false') |
+-------------------------------+
| true                          |
+-------------------------------+

mysql> SELECT IF(2 = TRUE, 'true', 'false');
+-------------------------------+
| IF(2 = TRUE, 'true', 'false') |
+-------------------------------+
| false                         |
+-------------------------------+

mysql> SELECT IF(2 = FALSE, 'true', 'false');
+--------------------------------+
| IF(2 = FALSE, 'true', 'false') |
+--------------------------------+
| false                          |
+--------------------------------+

      The last two statements display the results shown because 2 is equal to neither 1 nor 0.

    • SMALLINT[(*M*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      A small integer. The signed range is -32768 to 32767. The unsigned range is 0 to 65535.

    • MEDIUMINT[(*M*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      A medium-sized integer. The signed range is -8388608 to 8388607. The unsigned range is 0 to 16777215.

    • INT[(*M*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      A normal-size integer. The signed range is -2147483648 to 2147483647. The unsigned range is 0 to 4294967295.

    • INTEGER[(*M*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      This type is a synonym for INTopen in new window.

    • BIGINT[(*M*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      A large integer. The signed range is -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807. The unsigned range is 0 to 18446744073709551615.

      SERIAL is an alias for BIGINT UNSIGNED NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT UNIQUE.

      Some things you should be aware of with respect to BIGINTopen in new window columns:

      • All arithmetic is done using signed BIGINTopen in new window or DOUBLEopen in new window values, so you should not use unsigned big integers larger than 9223372036854775807 (63 bits) except with bit functions! If you do that, some of the last digits in the result may be wrong because of rounding errors when converting a BIGINTopen in new window value to a DOUBLEopen in new window.

        MySQL can handle BIGINTopen in new window in the following cases:

        • When using integers to store large unsigned values in a BIGINTopen in new window column.
        • In MIN(*col_name*)open in new window or MAX(*col_name*)open in new window, where col_name refers to a BIGINTopen in new window column.
        • When using operators (+open in new window, -open in new window, *open in new window, and so on) where both operands are integers.

      • You can always store an exact integer value in a BIGINTopen in new window column by storing it using a string. In this case, MySQL performs a string-to-number conversion that involves no intermediate double-precision representation.

      • The -open in new window, +open in new window, and *open in new window operators use BIGINTopen in new window arithmetic when both operands are integer values. This means that if you multiply two big integers (or results from functions that return integers), you may get unexpected results when the result is larger than 9223372036854775807.

    • DECIMAL[(*M*[,*D*\])] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      A packed â€œexactâ€ fixed-point number. M is the total number of digits (the precision) and D is the number of digits after the decimal point (the scale). The decimal point and (for negative numbers) the - sign are not counted in M. If D is 0, values have no decimal point or fractional part. The maximum number of digits (M) for DECIMALopen in new window is 65. The maximum number of supported decimals (D) is 30. If D is omitted, the default is 0. If M is omitted, the default is 10. (There is also a limit on how long the text of DECIMALopen in new window literals can be; see Section 12.25.3, â€œExpression Handlingâ€open in new window.)

      UNSIGNED, if specified, disallows negative values. As of MySQL 8.0.17, the UNSIGNED attribute is deprecated for columns of type DECIMALopen in new window (and any synonyms); you should expect support for it to be removed in a future version of MySQL. Consider using a simple CHECK constraint instead for such columns.

      All basic calculations (+, -, *, /) with DECIMALopen in new window columns are done with a precision of 65 digits.

    • DEC[(*M*[,*D*\])] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window, NUMERIC[(*M*[,*D*\])] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window, FIXED[(*M*[,*D*\])] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      These types are synonyms for DECIMALopen in new window. The FIXEDopen in new window synonym is available for compatibility with other database systems.

    • FLOAT[(*M*,*D*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      A small (single-precision) floating-point number. Permissible values are -3.402823466E+38 to -1.175494351E-38, 0, and 1.175494351E-38 to 3.402823466E+38. These are the theoretical limits, based on the IEEE standard. The actual range might be slightly smaller depending on your hardware or operating system.

      M is the total number of digits and D is the number of digits following the decimal point. If M and D are omitted, values are stored to the limits permitted by the hardware. A single-precision floating-point number is accurate to approximately 7 decimal places.

      FLOAT(*M*,*D*) is a nonstandard MySQL extension. As of MySQL 8.0.17, this syntax is deprecated, and you should expect support for it to be removed in a future version of MySQL.

      UNSIGNED, if specified, disallows negative values. As of MySQL 8.0.17, the UNSIGNED attribute is deprecated for columns of type FLOATopen in new window (and any synonyms) and you should expect support for it to be removed in a future version of MySQL. Consider using a simple CHECK constraint instead for such columns.

      Using FLOATopen in new window might give you some unexpected problems because all calculations in MySQL are done with double precision. See Section B.3.4.7, â€œSolving Problems with No Matching Rowsâ€open in new window.

    • FLOAT(*p*) [UNSIGNED\] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      A floating-point number. p represents the precision in bits, but MySQL uses this value only to determine whether to use FLOATopen in new window or DOUBLEopen in new window for the resulting data type. If p is from 0 to 24, the data type becomes FLOATopen in new window with no M or D values. If p is from 25 to 53, the data type becomes DOUBLEopen in new window with no M or D values. The range of the resulting column is the same as for the single-precision FLOATopen in new window or double-precision DOUBLEopen in new window data types described earlier in this section.

      UNSIGNED, if specified, disallows negative values. As of MySQL 8.0.17, the UNSIGNED attribute is deprecated for columns of type FLOATopen in new window (and any synonyms) and you should expect support for it to be removed in a future version of MySQL. Consider using a simple CHECK constraint instead for such columns.

      FLOAT(*p*)open in new window syntax is provided for ODBC compatibility.

    • DOUBLE[(*M*,*D*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      A normal-size (double-precision) floating-point number. Permissible values are -1.7976931348623157E+308 to -2.2250738585072014E-308, 0, and 2.2250738585072014E-308 to 1.7976931348623157E+308. These are the theoretical limits, based on the IEEE standard. The actual range might be slightly smaller depending on your hardware or operating system.

      M is the total number of digits and D is the number of digits following the decimal point. If M and D are omitted, values are stored to the limits permitted by the hardware. A double-precision floating-point number is accurate to approximately 15 decimal places.

      DOUBLE(*M*,*D*) is a nonstandard MySQL extension. As of MySQL 8.0.17, this syntax is deprecated and you should expect support for it to be removed in a future version of MySQL.

      UNSIGNED, if specified, disallows negative values. As of MySQL 8.0.17, the UNSIGNED attribute is deprecated for columns of type DOUBLEopen in new window (and any synonyms) and you should expect support for it to be removed in a future version of MySQL. Consider using a simple CHECK constraint instead for such columns.

    • DOUBLE PRECISION[(*M*,*D*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window, REAL[(*M*,*D*)\] [UNSIGNED] [ZEROFILL]open in new window

      These types are synonyms for DOUBLEopen in new window. Exception: If the REAL_AS_FLOATopen in new window SQL mode is enabled, REALopen in new window is a synonym for FLOATopen in new window rather than DOUBLEopen in new window.

    # 3.2æ—¥æœŸ

    The date and time data types for representing temporal values are DATEopen in new window, TIMEopen in new window, DATETIMEopen in new window, TIMESTAMPopen in new window, and YEARopen in new window.

    For the DATEopen in new window and DATETIMEopen in new window range descriptions, â€œsupportedâ€ means that although earlier values might work, there is no guarantee.

    MySQL permits fractional seconds for TIMEopen in new window, DATETIMEopen in new window, and TIMESTAMPopen in new window values, with up to microseconds (6 digits) precision. To define a column that includes a fractional seconds part, use the syntax *type_name*(*fsp*), where type_name is TIMEopen in new window, DATETIMEopen in new window, or TIMESTAMPopen in new window, and fsp is the fractional seconds precision. For example:

    CREATE TABLE t1 (t TIME(3), dt DATETIME(6), ts TIMESTAMP(0));

    The fsp value, if given, must be in the range 0 to 6. A value of 0 signifies that there is no fractional part. If omitted, the default precision is 0. (This differs from the standard SQL default of 6, for compatibility with previous MySQL versions.)

    Any TIMESTAMPopen in new window or DATETIMEopen in new window column in a table can have automatic initialization and updating properties; see Section 11.2.5, â€œAutomatic Initialization and Updating for TIMESTAMP and DATETIMEâ€open in new window.

    • DATEopen in new window

      A date. The supported range is '1000-01-01' to '9999-12-31'. MySQL displays DATEopen in new window values in '*YYYY-MM-DD*' format, but permits assignment of values to DATEopen in new window columns using either strings or numbers.

    • DATETIME[(*fsp*)\]open in new window

      A date and time combination. The supported range is '1000-01-01 00:00:00.000000' to '9999-12-31 23:59:59.999999'. MySQL displays DATETIMEopen in new window values in '*YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss*[.*fraction*]' format, but permits assignment of values to DATETIMEopen in new window columns using either strings or numbers.

      An optional fsp value in the range from 0 to 6 may be given to specify fractional seconds precision. A value of 0 signifies that there is no fractional part. If omitted, the default precision is 0.

      Automatic initialization and updating to the current date and time for DATETIMEopen in new window columns can be specified using DEFAULT and ON UPDATE column definition clauses, as described in Section 11.2.5, â€œAutomatic Initialization and Updating for TIMESTAMP and DATETIMEâ€open in new window.

    • TIMESTAMP[(*fsp*)\]open in new window

      A timestamp. The range is '1970-01-01 00:00:01.000000' UTC to '2038-01-19 03:14:07.999999' UTC. TIMESTAMPopen in new window values are stored as the number of seconds since the epoch ('1970-01-01 00:00:00' UTC). A TIMESTAMPopen in new window cannot represent the value '1970-01-01 00:00:00' because that is equivalent to 0 seconds from the epoch and the value 0 is reserved for representing '0000-00-00 00:00:00', the â€œzeroâ€ TIMESTAMPopen in new window value.

      An optional fsp value in the range from 0 to 6 may be given to specify fractional seconds precision. A value of 0 signifies that there is no fractional part. If omitted, the default precision is 0.

      The way the server handles TIMESTAMP definitions depends on the value of the explicit_defaults_for_timestampopen in new window system variable (see Section 5.1.8, â€œServer System Variablesâ€open in new window).

      If explicit_defaults_for_timestampopen in new window is enabled, there is no automatic assignment of the DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP or ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP attributes to any TIMESTAMPopen in new window column. They must be included explicitly in the column definition. Also, any TIMESTAMPopen in new window not explicitly declared as NOT NULL permits NULL values.

      If explicit_defaults_for_timestampopen in new window is disabled, the server handles TIMESTAMP as follows:

      Unless specified otherwise, the first TIMESTAMPopen in new window column in a table is defined to be automatically set to the date and time of the most recent modification if not explicitly assigned a value. This makes TIMESTAMPopen in new window useful for recording the timestamp of an INSERTopen in new window or UPDATEopen in new window operation. You can also set any TIMESTAMPopen in new window column to the current date and time by assigning it a NULL value, unless it has been defined with the NULL attribute to permit NULL values.

      Automatic initialization and updating to the current date and time can be specified using DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP and ON UPDATE CURRENT_TIMESTAMP column definition clauses. By default, the first TIMESTAMPopen in new window column has these properties, as previously noted. However, any TIMESTAMPopen in new window column in a table can be defined to have these properties.

    • TIME[(*fsp*)\]open in new window

      A time. The range is '-838:59:59.000000' to '838:59:59.000000'. MySQL displays TIMEopen in new window values in '*hh:mm:ss*[.*fraction*]' format, but permits assignment of values to TIMEopen in new window columns using either strings or numbers.

      An optional fsp value in the range from 0 to 6 may be given to specify fractional seconds precision. A value of 0 signifies that there is no fractional part. If omitted, the default precision is 0.

    • YEAR[(4)\]open in new window

      A year in 4-digit format. MySQL displays YEARopen in new window values in YYYY format, but permits assignment of values to YEARopen in new window columns using either strings or numbers. Values display as 1901 to 2155, or 0000.

      For additional information about YEARopen in new window display format and interpretation of input values, see Section 11.2.4, â€œThe YEAR Typeâ€open in new window.

      Note

      As of MySQL 8.0.19, the YEAR(4)open in new window data type with an explicit display width is deprecated; you should expect support for it to be removed in a future version of MySQL. Instead, use YEARopen in new window without a display width, which has the same meaning.

      MySQL 8.0 does not support the 2-digit YEAR(2)open in new window data type permitted in older versions of MySQL. For instructions on converting to 4-digit YEARopen in new window, see 2-Digit YEAR(2) Limitations and Migrating to 4-Digit YEARopen in new window, in MySQL 5.7 Reference Manualopen in new window.

    The SUM()open in new window and AVG()open in new window aggregate functions do not work with temporal values. (They convert the values to numbers, losing everything after the first nonnumeric character.) To work around this problem, convert to numeric units, perform the aggregate operation, and convert back to a temporal value. Examples:

    # 3.3å­—ç¬¦ä¸²

    The string data types are CHARopen in new window, VARCHARopen in new window, BINARYopen in new window, VARBINARYopen in new window, BLOBopen in new window, TEXTopen in new window, ENUMopen in new window, and SETopen in new window.

    In some cases, MySQL may change a string column to a type different from that given in a CREATE TABLEopen in new window or ALTER TABLEopen in new window statement. See Section 13.1.20.7, â€œSilent Column Specification Changesâ€open in new window.

    For definitions of character string columns (CHARopen in new window, VARCHARopen in new window, and the TEXTopen in new window types), MySQL interprets length specifications in character units. For definitions of binary string columns (BINARYopen in new window, VARBINARYopen in new window, and the BLOBopen in new window types), MySQL interprets length specifications in byte units.

    Column definitions for character string data types CHARopen in new window, VARCHARopen in new window, the TEXTopen in new window types, ENUMopen in new window, SETopen in new window, and any synonyms) can specify the column character set and collation:

    • CHARACTER SET specifies the character set. If desired, a collation for the character set can be specified with the COLLATE attribute, along with any other attributes. For example:

      CREATE TABLE t
(
    c1 VARCHAR(20) CHARACTER SET utf8mb4,
    c2 TEXT CHARACTER SET latin1 COLLATE latin1_general_cs
);

      This table definition creates a column named c1 that has a character set of utf8mb4 with the default collation for that character set, and a column named c2 that has a character set of latin1 and a case-sensitive (_cs) collation.

      The rules for assigning the character set and collation when either or both of CHARACTER SET and the COLLATE attribute are missing are described in Section 10.3.5, â€œColumn Character Set and Collationâ€open in new window.

      CHARSET is a synonym for CHARACTER SET.

    • Specifying the CHARACTER SET binary attribute for a character string data type causes the column to be created as the corresponding binary string data type: CHARopen in new window becomes BINARYopen in new window, VARCHARopen in new window becomes VARBINARYopen in new window, and TEXTopen in new window becomes BLOBopen in new window. For the ENUMopen in new window and SETopen in new window data types, this does not occur; they are created as declared. Suppose that you specify a table using this definition:

      CREATE TABLE t
(
  c1 VARCHAR(10) CHARACTER SET binary,
  c2 TEXT CHARACTER SET binary,
  c3 ENUM('a','b','c') CHARACTER SET binary
);

      The resulting table has this definition:

      CREATE TABLE t
(
  c1 VARBINARY(10),
  c2 BLOB,
  c3 ENUM('a','b','c') CHARACTER SET binary
);

    • The BINARY attribute is a nonstandard MySQL extension that is shorthand for specifying the binary (_bin) collation of the column character set (or of the table default character set if no column character set is specified). In this case, comparison and sorting are based on numeric character code values. Suppose that you specify a table using this definition:

      CREATE TABLE t
(
  c1 VARCHAR(10) CHARACTER SET latin1 BINARY,
  c2 TEXT BINARY
) CHARACTER SET utf8mb4;

      The resulting table has this definition:

      CREATE TABLE t (
  c1 VARCHAR(10) CHARACTER SET latin1 COLLATE latin1_bin,
  c2 TEXT CHARACTER SET utf8mb4 COLLATE utf8mb4_bin
) CHARACTER SET utf8mb4;

      In MySQL 8.0, this nonstandard use of the BINARY attribute is ambiguous because the utf8mb4 character set has multiple _bin collations. As of MySQL 8.0.17, the BINARY attribute is deprecated and you should expect support for it to be removed in a future version of MySQL. Applications should be adjusted to use an explicit _bin collation instead.

      The use of BINARY to specify a data type or character set remains unchanged.

    • The ASCII attribute is shorthand for CHARACTER SET latin1. Supported in older MySQL releases, ASCII is deprecated in MySQL 8.0.28 and later; use CHARACTER SET instead.

    • The UNICODE attribute is shorthand for CHARACTER SET ucs2. Supported in older MySQL releases, UNICODE is deprecated in MySQL 8.0.28 and later; use CHARACTER SET instead.

    Character column comparison and sorting are based on the collation assigned to the column. For the CHARopen in new window, VARCHARopen in new window, TEXTopen in new window, ENUMopen in new window, and SETopen in new window data types, you can declare a column with a binary (_bin) collation or the BINARY attribute to cause comparison and sorting to use the underlying character code values rather than a lexical ordering.

    For additional information about use of character sets in MySQL, see Chapter 10, Character Sets, Collations, Unicodeopen in new window.

    • [NATIONAL] CHAR[(*M*)] [CHARACTER SET *charset_name*] [COLLATE *collation_name*]

      A fixed-length string that is always right-padded with spaces to the specified length when stored. M represents the column length in characters. The range of M is 0 to 255. If M is omitted, the length is 1.

      Note

      Trailing spaces are removed when CHARopen in new window values are retrieved unless the PAD_CHAR_TO_FULL_LENGTHopen in new window SQL mode is enabled.

      CHARopen in new window is shorthand for CHARACTERopen in new window. NATIONAL CHARopen in new window (or its equivalent short form, NCHARopen in new window) is the standard SQL way to define that a CHARopen in new window column should use some predefined character set. MySQL uses utf8mb3 as this predefined character set. Section 10.3.7, â€œThe National Character Setâ€open in new window.

      The CHAR BYTEopen in new window data type is an alias for the BINARYopen in new window data type. This is a compatibility feature.

      MySQL permits you to create a column of type CHAR(0). This is useful primarily when you must be compliant with old applications that depend on the existence of a column but that do not actually use its value. CHAR(0) is also quite nice when you need a column that can take only two values: A column that is defined as CHAR(0) NULL occupies only one bit and can take only the values NULL and '' (the empty string).

    • [NATIONAL] VARCHAR(*M*) [CHARACTER SET *charset_name*] [COLLATE *collation_name*]

      A variable-length string. M represents the maximum column length in characters. The range of M is 0 to 65,535. The effective maximum length of a VARCHARopen in new window is subject to the maximum row size (65,535 bytes, which is shared among all columns) and the character set used. For example, utf8mb3 characters can require up to three bytes per character, so a VARCHARopen in new window column that uses the utf8mb3 character set can be declared to be a maximum of 21,844 characters. See Section 8.4.7, â€œLimits on Table Column Count and Row Sizeâ€open in new window.

      MySQL stores VARCHARopen in new window values as a 1-byte or 2-byte length prefix plus data. The length prefix indicates the number of bytes in the value. A VARCHARopen in new window column uses one length byte if values require no more than 255 bytes, two length bytes if values may require more than 255 bytes.

      Note

      MySQL follows the standard SQL specification, and does not remove trailing spaces from VARCHARopen in new window values.

      VARCHARopen in new window is shorthand for CHARACTER VARYINGopen in new window. NATIONAL VARCHARopen in new window is the standard SQL way to define that a VARCHARopen in new window column should use some predefined character set. MySQL uses utf8mb3 as this predefined character set. Section 10.3.7, â€œThe National Character Setâ€open in new window. NVARCHARopen in new window is shorthand for NATIONAL VARCHARopen in new window.

    • BINARY[(*M*)\]open in new window

      The BINARYopen in new window type is similar to the CHARopen in new window type, but stores binary byte strings rather than nonbinary character strings. An optional length M represents the column length in bytes. If omitted, M defaults to 1.

    • VARBINARY(*M*)open in new window

      The VARBINARYopen in new window type is similar to the VARCHARopen in new window type, but stores binary byte strings rather than nonbinary character strings. M represents the maximum column length in bytes.

    • TINYBLOBopen in new window

      A BLOBopen in new window column with a maximum length of 255 (28 âˆ’ 1) bytes. Each TINYBLOBopen in new window value is stored using a 1-byte length prefix that indicates the number of bytes in the value.

    • TINYTEXT [CHARACTER SET *charset_name*\] [COLLATE *collation_name*]open in new window

      A TEXTopen in new window column with a maximum length of 255 (28 âˆ’ 1) characters. The effective maximum length is less if the value contains multibyte characters. Each TINYTEXTopen in new window value is stored using a 1-byte length prefix that indicates the number of bytes in the value.

    • BLOB[(*M*)\]open in new window

      A BLOBopen in new window column with a maximum length of 65,535 (216 âˆ’ 1) bytes. Each BLOBopen in new window value is stored using a 2-byte length prefix that indicates the number of bytes in the value.

      An optional length M can be given for this type. If this is done, MySQL creates the column as the smallest BLOBopen in new window type large enough to hold values M bytes long.

    • TEXT[(*M*)\] [CHARACTER SET *charset_name*] [COLLATE *collation_name*]open in new window

      A TEXTopen in new window column with a maximum length of 65,535 (216 âˆ’ 1) characters. The effective maximum length is less if the value contains multibyte characters. Each TEXTopen in new window value is stored using a 2-byte length prefix that indicates the number of bytes in the value.

      An optional length M can be given for this type. If this is done, MySQL creates the column as the smallest TEXTopen in new window type large enough to hold values M characters long.

    • MEDIUMBLOBopen in new window

      A BLOBopen in new window column with a maximum length of 16,777,215 (224 âˆ’ 1) bytes. Each MEDIUMBLOBopen in new window value is stored using a 3-byte length prefix that indicates the number of bytes in the value.

    • MEDIUMTEXT [CHARACTER SET *charset_name*\] [COLLATE *collation_name*]open in new window

      A TEXTopen in new window column with a maximum length of 16,777,215 (224 âˆ’ 1) characters. The effective maximum length is less if the value contains multibyte characters. Each MEDIUMTEXTopen in new window value is stored using a 3-byte length prefix that indicates the number of bytes in the value.

    • LONGBLOBopen in new window

      A BLOBopen in new window column with a maximum length of 4,294,967,295 or 4GB (232 âˆ’ 1) bytes. The effective maximum length of LONGBLOBopen in new window columns depends on the configured maximum packet size in the client/server protocol and available memory. Each LONGBLOBopen in new window value is stored using a 4-byte length prefix that indicates the number of bytes in the value.

    • LONGTEXT [CHARACTER SET *charset_name*\] [COLLATE *collation_name*]open in new window

      A TEXTopen in new window column with a maximum length of 4,294,967,295 or 4GB (232 âˆ’ 1) characters. The effective maximum length is less if the value contains multibyte characters. The effective maximum length of LONGTEXTopen in new window columns also depends on the configured maximum packet size in the client/server protocol and available memory. Each LONGTEXTopen in new window value is stored using a 4-byte length prefix that indicates the number of bytes in the value.

    • ENUM('*value1*','*value2*',...) [CHARACTER SET *charset_name*\] [COLLATE *collation_name*]open in new window

      An enumeration. A string object that can have only one value, chosen from the list of values '*value1*', '*value2*', ..., NULL or the special '' error value. ENUMopen in new window values are represented internally as integers.

      An ENUMopen in new window column can have a maximum of 65,535 distinct elements.

      The maximum supported length of an individual ENUM element is M <= 255 and (M x w) <= 1020, where M is the element literal length and w is the number of bytes required for the maximum-length character in the character set.

    • SET('*value1*','*value2*',...) [CHARACTER SET *charset_name*\] [COLLATE *collation_name*]open in new window

      A set. A string object that can have zero or more values, each of which must be chosen from the list of values '*value1*', '*value2*', ... SETopen in new window values are represented internally as integers.

      A SETopen in new window column can have a maximum of 64 distinct members.

      The maximum supported length of an individual SET element is M <= 255 and (M x w) <= 1020, where M is the element literal length and w is the number of bytes required for the maximum-length character in the character set.

    # 3.4å…¶ä»–

    MySQL has spatial data types that correspond to OpenGIS classes. The basis for these types is described in Section 11.4.2, â€œThe OpenGIS Geometry Modelâ€open in new window.

    Some spatial data types hold single geometry values:

    • GEOMETRY
    • POINT
    • LINESTRING
    • POLYGON

    GEOMETRY can store geometry values of any type. The other single-value types (POINT, LINESTRING, and POLYGON) restrict their values to a particular geometry type.

    The other spatial data types hold collections of values:

    • MULTIPOINT
    • MULTILINESTRING
    • MULTIPOLYGON
    • GEOMETRYCOLLECTION

    GEOMETRYCOLLECTION can store a collection of objects of any type. The other collection types (MULTIPOINT, MULTILINESTRING, and MULTIPOLYGON) restrict collection members to those having a particular geometry type.

    Example: To create a table named geom that has a column named g that can store values of any geometry type, use this statement:

    CREATE TABLE geom (g GEOMETRY);

    Columns with a spatial data type can have an SRID attribute, to explicitly indicate the spatial reference system (SRS) for values stored in the column. For example:

    CREATE TABLE geom (
    p POINT SRID 0,
    g GEOMETRY NOT NULL SRID 4326
);

    SPATIAL indexes can be created on spatial columns if they are NOT NULL and have a specific SRID, so if you plan to index the column, declare it with the NOT NULL and SRID attributes:

    CREATE TABLE geom (g GEOMETRY NOT NULL SRID 4326);

    InnoDB tables permit SRID values for Cartesian and geographic SRSs. MyISAM tables permit SRID values for Cartesian SRSs.

    The SRID attribute makes a spatial column SRID-restricted, which has these implications:

    • The column can contain only values with the given SRID. Attempts to insert values with a different SRID produce an error.
    • The optimizer can use SPATIAL indexes on the column. See Section 8.3.3, â€œSPATIAL Index Optimizationâ€open in new window.

    Spatial columns with no SRID attribute are not SRID-restricted and accept values with any SRID. However, the optimizer cannot use SPATIAL indexes on them until the column definition is modified to include an SRID attribute, which may require that the column contents first be modified so that all values have the same SRID.

    For other examples showing how to use spatial data types in MySQL, see Section 11.4.6, â€œCreating Spatial Columnsâ€open in new window. For information about spatial reference systems, see Section 11.4.5, â€œSpatial Reference System Supportâ€open in new window.

    # 2.ç´¢å¼•

    # 2.1ç´¢å¼•çš„æ•°æ®ç»“æ„

    Understanding the B-tree and hash data structures can help predict how different queries perform on different storage engines that use these data structures in their indexes, particularly for the MEMORY storage engine that lets you choose B-tree or hash indexes.

    • B-Tree Index Characteristicsopen in new window
    • Hash Index Characteristicsopen in new window

    # B-Tree Index Characteristics

    A B-tree index can be used for column comparisons in expressions that use the =open in new window, >open in new window, >=open in new window, <open in new window, <=open in new window, or BETWEENopen in new window operators. The index also can be used for LIKEopen in new window comparisons if the argument to LIKEopen in new window is a constant string that does not start with a wildcard character. For example, the following SELECTopen in new window statements use indexes:

    SELECT * FROM tbl_name WHERE key_col LIKE 'Patrick%';
SELECT * FROM tbl_name WHERE key_col LIKE 'Pat%_ck%';

    In the first statement, only rows with 'Patrick' <= *key_col* < 'Patricl' are considered. In the second statement, only rows with 'Pat' <= *key_col* < 'Pau' are considered.

    The following SELECTopen in new window statements do not use indexes:

    SELECT * FROM tbl_name WHERE key_col LIKE '%Patrick%';
SELECT * FROM tbl_name WHERE key_col LIKE other_col;

    In the first statement, the LIKEopen in new window value begins with a wildcard character. In the second statement, the LIKEopen in new window value is not a constant.

    If you use ... LIKE '%*string*%' and string is longer than three characters, MySQL uses the Turbo Boyer-Moore algorithm to initialize the pattern for the string and then uses this pattern to perform the search more quickly.

    A search using *col_name* IS NULL employs indexes if col_name is indexed.

    Any index that does not span all ANDopen in new window levels in the WHERE clause is not used to optimize the query. In other words, to be able to use an index, a prefix of the index must be used in every ANDopen in new window group.

    The following WHERE clauses use indexes:

    ... WHERE index_part1=1 AND index_part2=2 AND other_column=3

    /* index = 1 OR index = 2 */
... WHERE index=1 OR A=10 AND index=2

    /* optimized like "index_part1='hello'" */
... WHERE index_part1='hello' AND index_part3=5

    /* Can use index on index1 but not on index2 or index3 */
... WHERE index1=1 AND index2=2 OR index1=3 AND index3=3;

    These WHERE clauses do not use indexes:

        /* index_part1 is not used */
... WHERE index_part2=1 AND index_part3=2

    /*  Index is not used in both parts of the WHERE clause  */
... WHERE index=1 OR A=10

    /* No index spans all rows  */
... WHERE index_part1=1 OR index_part2=10

    Sometimes MySQL does not use an index, even if one is available. One circumstance under which this occurs is when the optimizer estimates that using the index would require MySQL to access a very large percentage of the rows in the table. (In this case, a table scan is likely to be much faster because it requires fewer seeks.) However, if such a query uses LIMIT to retrieve only some of the rows, MySQL uses an index anyway, because it can much more quickly find the few rows to return in the result.

    # Hash Index Characteristics

    Hash indexes have somewhat different characteristics from those just discussed:

    • They are used only for equality comparisons that use the = or <=> operators (but are very fast). They are not used for comparison operators such as < that find a range of values. Systems that rely on this type of single-value lookup are known as â€œkey-value storesâ€; to use MySQL for such applications, use hash indexes wherever possible.
    • The optimizer cannot use a hash index to speed up ORDER BY operations. (This type of index cannot be used to search for the next entry in order.)
    • MySQL cannot determine approximately how many rows there are between two values (this is used by the range optimizer to decide which index to use). This may affect some queries if you change a MyISAM or InnoDB table to a hash-indexed MEMORY table.
    • Only whole keys can be used to search for a row. (With a B-tree index, any leftmost prefix of the key can be used to find rows.)

    The following diagram shows in-memory and on-disk structures that comprise the InnoDB storage engine architecture. For information about each structure, see Section 15.5, â€œInnoDB In-Memory Structuresâ€open in new window, and Section 15.6, â€œInnoDB On-Disk Structuresâ€open in new window.
